title: How to Make an RJ‐45 Cable

steps.headline: Adjust the dial of the wire stripper.
steps.description: Twist the dial until it can cut into your cable without damaging the wires inside. Make sure that it is the right dial to match the size of your cable.

steps.headline: Insert the wire into the notch.
steps.description: Stick the wire into the notch of the wire stripper and gently squeeze the stripper, so it can cut through the rubber cushioning/insulation. Check to see if the length of the cable is not too short or too long as your inserting it into the notch.

steps.headline: Cut through the insulation.
steps.description: Spin the wire stripper around the wire once it cuts the rubber insulation to make sure that the insulation is cut all the way through. Double check to make sure that the inner wires are not damaged, to prevent issues from occurring as you continue!

steps.headline: Pull off the cut insulation so that the inner wires are exposed.
Untwist the wires.
steps.description: Make it so the colored wires are separated from each other.

steps.headline: Organize the wires.
steps.description: The wires should be organized using the straight through method. Both T-568A and T-569B will work, so pick one of the patterns and apply it to both sides of the cable.

steps.headline: Check the length.
steps.description: Line up the wiring with connectors to see if the length is good.

steps.headline: Cut the excess if the length is longer than needed.
Insert the wires in the connector.
steps.description: Slide the wires inside the connector so that it is all the way though.

steps.headline: Crimp the connector.
steps.description: Use the crimping tool by squeezing the connector relatively hard to secure the wires inside the connector.

steps.headline: Double check that all the wires are in the correct order
Use the crimper on cables.
steps.description: Be careful because after this point you can not redo anything

steps.headline: Test the cables.
steps.description: Test the cables by inserting it into a cable tester or the back end of a router.

steps.headline: Plug in the cables for use!

tyn: Crimper (Note: some crimpers come with a wire cutter)
Cabling: Choose from Cat5, Cat5e (most common), Cat6, Cat6a, Cat7 (When deciding on what cable you are looking for, you should keep two things in mind: speed and cost.)
text: Stripping the Protective Casing Adjust the dial of the wire stripper. Twist the dial until it can cut into your cable without damaging the wires inside. Make sure that it is the right dial to match the size of your cable. Insert the wire into the notch. Stick the wire into the notch of the wire stripper and gently squeeze the stripper, so it can cut through the rubber cushioning/insulation. Check to see if the length of the cable is not too short or too long as your inserting it into the notch. Cut through the insulation. Spin the wire stripper around the wire once it cuts the rubber insulation to make sure that the insulation is cut all the way through. Double check to make sure that the inner wires are not damaged, to prevent issues from occurring as you continue! Exposung and Organizing the Wires Pull off the cut insulation so that the inner wires are exposed.  Untwist the wires. Make it so the colored wires are separated from each other. Organize the wires. The wires should be organized using the straight through method. Both T-568A and T-569B will work, so pick one of the patterns and apply it to both sides of the cable. Check the length. Line up the wiring with connectors to see if the length is good. Cut the excess if the length is longer than needed.  Connecting Everything Together Insert the wires in the connector. Slide the wires inside the connector so that it is all the way though. Crimp the connector. Use the crimping tool by squeezing the connector relatively hard to secure the wires inside the connector. Double check that all the wires are in the correct order  Use the crimper on cables. Be careful because after this point you can not redo anything Test the cables. Test the cables by inserting it into a cable tester or the back end of a router. Plug in the cables for use!
sentences: Stripping the Protective Casing Adjust the dial of the wire stripper.
Twist the dial until it can cut into your cable without damaging the wires inside.
Make sure that it is the right dial to match the size of your cable.
Insert the wire into the notch.
Stick the wire into the notch of the wire stripper and gently squeeze the stripper, so it can cut through the rubber cushioning/insulation.
Check to see if the length of the cable is not too short or too long as your inserting it into the notch.
Cut through the insulation.
Spin the wire stripper around the wire once it cuts the rubber insulation to make sure that the insulation is cut all the way through.
Double check to make sure that the inner wires are not damaged, to prevent issues from occurring as you continue!
Exposung and Organizing the Wires Pull off the cut insulation so that the inner wires are exposed.
Untwist the wires.
Make it so the colored wires are separated from each other.
Organize the wires.
The wires should be organized using the straight through method.
Both T-568A and T-569B will work, so pick one of the patterns and apply it to both sides of the cable.
Check the length.
Line up the wiring with connectors to see if the length is good.
Cut the excess if the length is longer than needed.
Connecting Everything Together Insert the wires in the connector.
Slide the wires inside the connector so that it is all the way though.
Crimp the connector.
Use the crimping tool by squeezing the connector relatively hard to secure the wires inside the connector.
Double check that all the wires are in the correct order  Use the crimper on cables.
Be careful because after this point you can not redo anything Test the cables.
Test the cables by inserting it into a cable tester or the back end of a router.
Plug in the cables for use!
